Coordination number dependence of Pt catalysts for catalytic decomposition of aqueous hydroxylammonium nitrate (HAN) Shu Liu Formal analysis a b 1 Yujia Han Formal analysis a c 1 Teng Zong Methodology a b Chaojie Wang Investigation a Ming Tian Writing – original draft a ⁎ Lin Li Resources a Wansheng Zhang Resources a Wentao Wang Resources a Xiaodong Wang Writing – review & editing a ⁎ a CAS Key Laboratory of Science and Technology on Applied Catalysis, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, 457 Zhongshan Road, Dalian 116023, China CAS Key Laboratory of Science and Technology on Applied Catalysis, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences 457 Zhongshan Road Dalian 116023 China CAS Key Laboratory of Science and Technology on Applied Catalysis, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, 457 Zhongshan Road, Dalian 116023, People's Republic of China b University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, No.19(A) Yuquan Road, Shijingshan District, Beijing 100049, China University of Chinese Academy of Sciences No.19(A) Yuquan Road, Shijingshan District Beijing 100049 China University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, No.19(A) Yuquan Road, Shijingshan District, Beijing 100049, China c Suzhou Laboratory, Suzhou, China Suzhou Laboratory Suzhou China Suzhou Laboratory, Suzhou, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. 1 These authors contributed to this paper equally. To uncover the relation between active metals structure and the adsorption, activation as well as its decomposition performance of hydroxylamine nitrate (HAN) that has been considered to be a promising low-toxicity monopropellant for spacecrafts, the performance of xPt/Al2O3 with various Pt loadings (x = 0.1, 0.5, 1 and 2, indicates the mass percentage of Pt) was evaluated in the aqueous HAN (10 wt%) decomposition. It was found that the both the NH3OH+ conversion and the turnover frequency (TOF) enhanced as Pt loadings increased while NO3 - was hardly converted at the temperature of lower than 120 ℃ for xPt/Al2O3, and 2Pt/Al2O3 exhibited the best activity with almost 100 % NH3OH+ conversion, 20 % NH4 + selectivity and 80 % N2O selectivity at around 120 ℃, respectively. This originated from the increased Pt coordinated number of active sites with sufficiently continuous Pt sites caused by its enhanced particle size with loadings, which was beneficial to the cracking of N-O, O-H and N-H bonds together thus the activation and conversion of NH3OH+ to NH4 + and N2O. Graphical Abstract Keywords Coordination number dependence Hydroxylamine nitrate Catalytic performance Adsorption and activation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The orbital and attitude control of aircrafts is achieved by the decomposition of propellants fed into the thruster to produce high-pressure and -temperature gases [1–3]. The market of monopropellant systems is being dominated by hydrazine thrusters for decades despite its toxic characteristics recognized [4,5]. As a result, it is of great significance to develop green monopropellant for safer handling and higher cost effectiveness compared with conventional hydrazine propellant in small spacecrafts and satellites. Hereinto, monopropellants based on an aqueous solution of hydroxylammonium nitrate (HAN) with chemical formula [NH3OH+][NO3 -] have received considerable attention due to their high energy density, a low freezing point, high solubility in aqueous media, green post combustion and chemical stability [6–8]. Compared with thermal decomposition that requires temperature > 130 ℃, catalytic decomposition is able to decrease the ignition temperature to less than 40 ℃ and exhibits higher reaction rate, which achieves higher decomposition efficiency with larger heat release, gas formation and without preheating catalysts [9–11]. At present, the study on the catalytic decomposition of HAN is less than that on thermal one and principally concentrates on the performance evaluation of catalysts including the supported metals and metal oxides [12]. The supported noble metals have been reported the most and it is generally accepted that Pt- [13,14] and Ir-based [15] catalysts exhibited higher decomposition activity with the onset temperature even at room temperature than the supported non-noble metals such as Cu-based [16] and the metal oxides such as cobalt-doped cerium oxides [17,18] and Mn-substituted Sr-based hexaaluminates[19]. In addition, the researchers studied the influence of various factors on the performance of supported Pt and Ir catalysts. For example, Si-doped Al2O3 supported Pt in the form of powder exhibited higher activity than its sphere counterpart due to a good contact between catalyst bed and monopropellant [20]. The similar behavior was also observed in supported Ir in which grain catalyst showed better performance compared with monolith one [21]. Besides the shape of catalysts, the influence of particle size of metals on the performance was also studied. Pt/Si-Al prepared by the impregnation presented higher activity than that prepared by the sol-gel due to smaller Pt particle size (2 nm vs. 50 nm) [22]. Ir/SiO2 with Ir particle size of around 2.4 nm exhibited higher activity than Ir/Al2O3 did with Ir particle size of about 1.3 nm [23]. To the best of our knowledge, the influence of particle size and electronic state of metals on the adsorption and activation of HAN as well as decomposition activity is still unknown. In the present work, the performance of xPt/Al2O3 with varied Pt loadings (x = 0.1, 0.5, 1 and 2 wt%) was evaluated for the decomposition of HAN aqueous solution (10 vol%). The results indicated that NH3OH+ conversion and turnover frequency (TOF) increased with Pt loadings and the former reached 100 % for 2Pt/Al2O3 at 120 ℃ with NH4 + selectivity of about 80 % and N2O selectivity of about 20 % while NO3 - was hardly converted below this temperature. A series of characterization results clarified that the coordinated number of Pt0 species enhanced due to the increased size of Pt nanoparticles with loadings, which facilitated the concurrent breakage of N-O, O-H and N-H bonds thus the activation and conversion of NH3OH+ to NH4 + and N2O. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of xPt/Al2O3 All the xPt/Al2O3 samples, in which x indicated theoretical mass fraction of Pt, were prepared by equal volume wetness impregnation method. Typically, to prepared 2Pt/Al2O3, H2PtCl6·6 H2O (1 g) was dissolved in ultrapure water (100 mL) with stirring to obtain a yellow Pt solution (7.42 mg/mL). 0.5 g γ- Al2O3(<28 mesh, 220 m2·g−1) was placed in a 3 mL glass vial by slowly adding dropwise 1.347 mL H2PtCl6 solution with shaking vigorously. After standing at room temperature overnight, the sample was dried at 100 ℃ for 12 h and was in situ reduced by a H2/Ar (2:5, v/v; 70 mL·min−1) atmosphere at 350 ℃ for 2 h (heating rate: 5 ℃·min−1) in a quartz tube microreactor. 2.2 Performance evaluations The performance evaluations were carried out in a high-pressure continuous flow fixed-bed reactor [24]. The catalyst sample (0.5 g, ＜28 mesh) was diluted with 0.5 g quartz sand (16–26 mesh, Guoyao, China) and then fixed at the middle of a 316 L stainless steel tube (10 mm ID). At both ends of the catalyst, 2 mL quartz sands (20–40 mesh, Tianjin University) were used to obtain a uniform fluid flow. The reactor was placed in a vertical electrical furnace with two thermocouples outside the reactor and below the catalyst bed. The system pressure was raised to 1 MPa before reaction to increase the boiling point of water and ensure the reaction environment of the liquid phase. Then hydroxylamine nitrate (10 wt% HAN aqueous solution) was introduced into the reaction tube at a flow rate of 0.5 mL/min with Ar at gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 12000 mL/(g·h). Prior to measurement, the catalyst was reduced in situ in a H2/Ar atmosphere (2:5, v/v; 70 mL·min−1) at 350 ℃ for 2 h. The outlet gas was detected and quantified by using GAM200 quadrupole mass spectrometer (MS) while liquid effluent was collected in a cold trap, sampled every 20 min and then analyzed by potentiometric titration with KMnO4 for NH3OH+ and in an ion chromatograph for NH4 + and NO3 -. The details of the sampling and detection of the liquid effluent could be seen in the Supporting Information. The calculations of NH3OH+ conversion, NO3 - conversion, N2O selectivity, N2 selectivity, NO selectivity, NH4 + selectivity, and nitrogen balance were given as followed. X NH 3 OH + ( % ) = W NH 3 O H + , in − W NH 3 O H + , out W NH 3 O H + , in × 100 % X NO 3 − ( % ) = C NO 3 − , in − C NO 3 − , out C NO 3 − , in × 100 % S N 2 O ( % ) = F × ∫ 0 t y N 2 O , out dt 22.4 F × ∫ 0 t y N 2 O , out + y N 2 , out + y NO , out dt 22.4 + C NH 4 + , out × t * Q M NH 4 + × 100 % S N 2 ( % ) = F × ∫ 0 t y N 2 , out dt 22.4 F × ∫ 0 t y N 2 O , out + y N 2 , out + y NO , out dt 22.4 + C NH 4 + , out × t * Q M NH 4 + × 100 % S NO ( % ) = F × ∫ 0 t y NO , out dt 22.4 F × ∫ 0 t y N 2 O , out + y N 2 , out + y NO , out dt 22.4 + C NH 4 + , out × t * Q M NH 4 + × 100 % S NH 4 + ( % ) = C NH 4 + , out * t * Q M NH 4 + F × ∫ 0 t y N 2 O , out + y N 2 , out + y NO , out dt 22.4 + C NH 4 + , out × t * Q M NH 4 + × 100 % Where F represents the gas flow rate in reduction step, C is the corresponding concentration in the liquid, y is the corresponding gas concentration, M is the mass of the material, and Q is the liquid flow. WNH3OH+ is calculated by potentiometric titration with KMnO4, CNO3- and CNH4+ was obtained in an ion chromatograph. 2.3 Characterization of xPt/Al2O3 The crystal phases of the sample were measured by PANalytical X′Pert-Pro powder X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation of 0.1541 nm. The scanned 2θ range was 10–90° at 40 kV and 40 mA. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface areas and the pore size distributions of xPt/Al2O3 were performed on a Micromeritics ASAP 2010 apparatus. The samples were degassed in a vacuum at 110 and 350 ℃ for 1 and 5 h before characterization, respectively. The adsorption–desorption isotherms were then measured at the temperature of liquid nitrogen (−196 ℃) using nitrogen as the adsorption gas. The specific surface areas were calculated by the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method and the pore size distributions were given by the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) model. The particle size and distribution of Pt in xPt/Al2O3 were identified by a field emission transmission electron microscope (JEOL JEM-2100F). The AC-HAADF-STEM analysis was performed on a JEOL JEM-ARM200F equipped with a CEOS probe corrector with a guaranteed resolution of 0.08 nm. The metal content of xPt/Al2O3 was determined using a PerkinElmer 7300DV ICP-OES spectrometer. Hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) and CO pulse chemisorption measurements were carried out on a Micromeritics Autochem II 2920. For the H2-TPR test, the sample (0.1 g) was firstly pretreated at 110 ℃ in Ar atmosphere for 30 min followed by cooled to 50 ℃. Then, the gas was switched to a 10 % H2/Ar (30 mL·min−1) and the temperature was increased from 50 to 600 ℃ with a heating rate of 10 ℃·min−1. For the CO-pulse experiment, 0.1 g of xPt/Al2O3 was pretreated in 10 % H2/Ar (30 mL·min−1) at a ramping rate of 10 ℃/min to 350 ℃ and maintained for 30 min. Then, Ar was purged into the tube with the rate of 30 mL·min−1 under 360 ℃ for 30 min to remove the surface adsorbed hydrogen. After cooling to 50 ℃, the CO pulse was injected every 6 min and its adsorption measurement was performed under this temperature. In-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (in-situ DRIFTS) was recorded on a Bruker EQUINOX 70 equipped with an in-situ DRIFTS cell and a mercury–cadmium–telluride (MCT) detector cooled by liquid N2. All of the samples were pretreated at 350 ℃ for 30 min under H2/He (2:5, v/v; 20 mL·min−1), followed by purging with He at 360 ℃ for 30 min, and then catalysts were cooled down to 20 ℃ under He. Each spectrum was performed by averaging 32 scans with a resolution of 4 cm−1 in the 4000–1000 cm−1 range under 20 ℃ to avoid background changes and temperature-induced features. For the in-situ CO-DRIFT test, after recording the background, the CO/He flow (1:4, v/v; 10 mL·min−1) was introduced into the cell, and the DRIFTS were collected every 1 min. When the adsorption was saturated, He (10 mL) entered into the cell and the spectra were collected every 1 min until the gas phase peak disappeared. For the in-situ DRIFTS with the introduction of NH2OH, a high purity He (10 mL·min−1) was feed into the reaction cell followed by the introduction of 10 wt% NH2OH aqueous solution after background data was recorded in 20 ℃ and 60 ℃, and the diffuse signals were collected every 1 min. 2.4 Computational details All first-principle calculations in this study were performed by the density functional theory (DFT) using the Vienna Ab-initio Simulation Package (VASP) code [25]. The generalized gradient approximation (GGA) with the exchange-correlation functional Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) was adopted to describe the electronic exchange and correlation effects [26–28]. The cutoff energy for the plane-wave basis was set to 500 eV in all the cases. To study the catalytic activity of metallic Pt, Pt(111) surface model was constructed based on our experiments and simulated by a p(3 ×3) slab consisting of 5 layers. During the geometric optimization, the top 2 layers together with the adsorbate were relaxed. A 15 Å vacuum layer was applied to separate the periodic model in the z-direction of the slab models. Numerical integration over the Brillouin zone was sampled with the Monkhorst-Pack grids with the density of one point per ∼0.03 Å−3 [29]. The convergence of geometric optimization was checked with the forces less than 0.03 eV Å−1 and the energy difference less than 10−6 eV. The D3 Grimme correction was adopted for the consideration of van der Waals (vdW) interactions in all reaction processes [30]. The nudged elastic band (NEB) combined with minimum-mode following dimer method was employed to obtain the transition state structure of the reaction [31]. Moreover, the calculations were considered converged when the maximum forces on all atoms were less than 0.05 eV Å−1. Meanwhile, the transition state was verified using the single imaginary frequency. The adsorption energy (E ads ) of HAN on Pt(111) surface is estimated by the following formula: Eads = EHAN+Pt(111) - EPt(111) - EHAN where E HAN+Pt(111) is the total energy of the Pt(111) adsorbed with HAN molecule, E Pt(111) is the total energy of Pt(111), and E HAN is the total energy of HAN molecule. The reaction energies (ΔE) of HAN on Pt(111) surface are estimated by the following formula: ΔE = E FS - E IS where E FS is the total energy of Pt(111) adsorbed with final species, E IS is the total energy of Pt(111) adsorbed with initial species. The activation energies (E a ) of HAN dissociation on Pt(111) surface are estimated by the following formula: E a = E TS - E IS where E TS is the total energy of transition state of HAN dissociated on Pt(111) surface, E IS is the total energy of Pt(111) adsorbed with initial species. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Performance evaluation of xPt/Al2O3 The performance tests were carried out in the pressured continuous-flow fixed bed reactor and the results are shown in Fig. 1, Figs. S1 and 2. Fig. 1 shows the activity of HAN aqueous solution decomposition over xPt/Al2O3. It could be seen that the NH3OH+ conversion increased with Pt loadings and 2Pt/Al2O3 exhibited the best activity with almost 100 % conversion at around 120 ℃. The turnover frequency (TOF) was also listed in Table 1 wherein it also increased with Pt loadings, indicating that higher activity might be attributed to distinct structure of active sites rather than Pt amounts. In addition, the NO3 - could hardly be converted over 0.1Pt/Al2O3, 0.5Pt/Al2O3 and 1Pt/Al2O3 at temperature of lower than 120 ℃, and it began to be converted at temperature of higher than 100 ℃ and reached about 50 % at 120 ℃ over 2Pt/Al2O3 (Fig. 1b), indicating that NH3OH+ was more easily activated and converted than NO3 - over xPt/Al2O3. The distribution of products at various reaction temperature is shown in Fig. 2. All the catalysts exhibited similar selectivity of NH4 + and N2O of about 70 % and 30 %, respectively, at temperature of lower than 120 ℃ while N2O selectivity significantly increased to around 80 % with the decrease in NH4 + selectivity to about 20 % over 2Pt/Al2O3 at 120 ℃. Combined with conversion results (Fig. 1), it could be concluded that NH3OH+ alone decomposed to produce NH4 + and N2O nitrogen-containing products at relatively low temperature (<100 ℃), as presented in the following equation: 4 NH 3 OH + → 2 NH 4 + + N 2 O + 2 H + + 3 H 2 O and then NO3 - participated in the reaction leading to the formation of larger amount of N2O at higher temperature, as presented in the following equation: NH 4 + + NO 3 − → N 2 O + 2 H 2 O 3.2 Characterization of xPt/Al2O3 Table 1 shows the detailed properties of the xPt/Al2O3 catalysts. The actual loadings of Pt analyzed by ICP-AES were close to the nominal values and the surface areas of catalysts with different loadings were 232 −277 m2/g with a slight increase after Pt introduction (220 m2·g−1 for Al2O3). The Pt dispersions determined by CO chemisorption declined along with the increase in Pt loading. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of xPt/Al2O3 are shown in Fig. 3. It could be observed that the peaks attributed to Al2O3 without those of Pt species could be detected due to high dispersion of Pt. HAADF-STEM and AC-TEM characterizations were carried out to study the particle sizes and distribution of Pt species. As shown in Fig. 4, small amount of Pt sub-nano clusters could be observed for 0.1Pt/Al2O3 with average particle size of about 1.1 nm (Fig. 4a, e, insets and Table 1). The number of Pt particles was few induced by low Pt loading (0.1 wt%), which might account for the discrepancy on Pt dispersion between TEM and CO chemisorption results. Following an increase of the Pt loadings, more Pt nanoparticles were detected with the increase in the average sizes to around 1.2 nm, 1.3 nm and 2.3 nm for 0.5Pt/Al2O3, 1Pt/Al2O3 and 2Pt/Al2O3, respectively (Fig. 4b-d, f, g, insets and Table 1), probably due to slight aggregation of Pt particles. Combined with the results of activity tests (Fig. 1), Pt nanoparticles with larger size should be favorable for NH3OH+ conversion. In-situ CO-DRIFT was employed to make sure the chemical state of Pt in xPt/Al2O3 after reduction under H2 atmosphere at 350 ℃ (Most of Pt in all the samples could be reduced at this temperature as shown in Fig. 5) and the results were shown in Fig. 6. The broad bands in the range between 1960 and 2100 cm−1 could be observed besides the two ones at 2176 cm−1 and 2112 cm−1 due to gaseous CO [32,33] for all the samples, which could be attributed to linear adsorption of CO on the metallic Pt sites [34,35], indicating that Pt was present in the form of metallic state. In addition, a new band at around 1820 cm−1 besides those between 1960 and 2100 cm−1 appeared with the increase in the Pt loadings, which could be assigned to bridged CO species adsorbed on neighboring Pt nanoparticles [36], indicating the presence of Pt with larger particle sizes in line with the results of HRTEM. In addition, blue-shift of the bands between 1960 and 2100 cm−1 occurred, which should be induced by the increase in the coordination number of Pt nanoparticle [34,36]. Such the well-coordinated Pt sites caused by the increase of particle size might be conductive to the adsorption and activation of NH3OH+ and thus its conversion. 3.3 Discussion At present, the study of catalytic decomposition of HAN principally focused on the performance evaluation of catalysts. To the best of our knowledge, the relationship between the adsorption and activation of bonds in HAN aqueous solution and activity has been rarely investigated, which was important for the design of catalysts with superior performance. Herein, in-situ DRIFT was employed to study the activation of bonds using hydroxylamine (10 wt% aqueous solution) as the probe molecule considering that the NO3 - was hardly converted at temperature lower than 100 ℃ (Fig. 1) in the present work. As shown in Fig. 7, a negative band at around 1100 cm−1 belonging to stretching vibration of N-O bonds in NH2OH [37] was observed for all the samples after feeding NH2OH aqueous solution for 20 min at 20 ℃ but its intensity increased with Pt loadings, which indicated the enhanced activation of N-O bonds. Moreover, three positive bands at about 1610 cm−1, 1565 cm−1 and 1450 cm−1 were detected for 0.1Pt/Al2O3, 0.5Pt/Al2O3 and 1Pt/Al2O3, which could be attributed to vibrational features of NH3 and NHx [38]. This indicated that NH3 should form by the activation and breakage of O-H bonds besides N-O ones on Pt sites. Distinct bands (1686 cm−1, 1390 cm−1 and 1270 cm−1) which were due to the vibration of NH4 + [39] were observed in 2Pt/Al2O3, indicating that O-H bonds could be activated more easily on 2Pt/Al2O3 leading to the formation of larger amount of NH3. In addition, an obvious band at about 1540 cm−1 was detected, which could be ascribed to HNO, a vital intermediate considered for the production of N2O [40]. This suggested that the N-H bonds which was reported to possess larger dissociation energy than N-O and O-H ones in NH2OH [41] also cracked except for the N-O and O-H ones. With the increase of the temperature to 60 ℃, all the samples exhibited similar bands at 1686 cm−1, 1480 cm−1, 1459 cm−1 and 1400 cm−1 attributed to the vibration of NH4 + accompanied with gaseous peaks of N2O (2240 cm−1 and 1280 cm−1), and two new bands at 1280 cm−1 and 1055 cm−1 ascribed to NH deformation adsorbed on metal sites [38] appeared on 2Pt/Al2O3 ( Fig. 8), indicating that the reaction extent became greater. However, their intensity increased with Pt loadings, which should be because the samples with larger Pt amount was more conductive to activating NH2OH. Combined with the characterization results (Fig. 6), it was speculated that the active sites with higher Pt coordinated number facilitated concurrent breakage of N-O, O-H and particular N-H bonds with larger dissociation energy and thus the activation and conversion of NH3OH+. To the best of our knowledge, the study on reaction mechanism mainly concentrated on thermal decomposition of HAN whereas that on catalytic decomposition whether experimental or theoretical has been seldom reported at present. Herein, we tried to calculate HAN adsorption and activation to form NH4* and O* on Pt(111), and the results are shown in Figs. 9 and S3. HAN adsorbed on two adjacent Pt sites in a bidentate bridging fashion via two O atoms from the NO3 - group. Then the N-O bond in NH3OH+ stretched and cleaved allowing the formation of OH* bridging adsorbed on two adjacent Pt sites and NH3*. As the H atom from OH moved closer to the N atom of NH3, the O-H bond broke leading to the formation of NH4 + and adsorbed O atom. This reaction was exothermic and the energy barrier of O-H bond breaking was higher than that of N-O doing (0.74 eV vs. 0.37 eV). The DFT calculations of reaction mechanism on the NO3 - conversion and N2O formation on the supported metal catalysts would be carried out combined with the development of efficient characterization techniques in the future work. 4 Conclusions In summary, NH3OH+ conversion and TOF increased with Pt loadings, and 2Pt/Al2O3 exhibited the best performance with NH3OH+ conversion of 100 %, NH4 + selectivity of about 20 % and N2O selectivity of about 80 % at 120 °C whereas NO3 - conversion was almost negligible below this temperature. This could be attributed to the enhancement of Pt coordination number with sufficiently continuous Pt ensemble as its loadings caused by the increase in the particle size, which improved the breakage of N-O, O-H and N-H bonds and thus the activation of NH3OH+. This work proposed a strategy to design highly efficient supported metals catalysts for aqueous HAN decomposition with suitable metal coordination number to promote the adsorption and activation for NH3OH+. coredata.dc:description: To uncover the relation between active metals structure and the adsorption, activation as well as its decomposition performance of hydroxylamine nitrate (HAN) that has been considered to be a promising low-toxicity monopropellant for spacecrafts, the performance of xPt/Al2O3 with various Pt loadings (x = 0.1, 0.5, 1 and 2, indicates the mass percentage of Pt) was evaluated in the aqueous HAN (10 wt%) decomposition. It was found that the both the NH3OH+ conversion and the turnover frequency (TOF) enhanced as Pt loadings increased while NO3 - was hardly converted at the temperature of lower than 120 ℃ for xPt/Al2O3, and 2Pt/Al2O3 exhibited the best activity with almost 100 % NH3OH+ conversion, 20 % NH4 + selectivity and 80 % N2O selectivity at around 120 ℃, respectively. This originated from the increased Pt coordinated number of active sites with sufficiently continuous Pt sites caused by its enhanced particle size with loadings, which was beneficial to the cracking of N-O, O-H and N-H bonds together thus the activation and conversion of NH3OH+ to NH4 + and N2O.
